body:
_From @tinius on January 14, 2016 1:47_

Seems to me that this would do it:

```
ca = OpenSSL.crypto.load_certificate(
            OpenSSL.crypto.FILETYPE_PEM,
            raw)
if ca.has_expired():
    raise CertExpiredException("mitmproxy's certificate has expired.")
```

That being said, is there a reason why we shouldn't just call create_store on the spot?

> That being said, is there a reason why we shouldn't just call create_store on the spot?

I'm not sure what's the best way, but silently replacing the CA (without user notification) is not really optimal. At the very least, we need some kind of notification that a new certificate has been generated.
Not sure yet. Let's start by adding a function in netlib that determines if the CA is outdated + tests? :smiley:

issue.title: Added method and test for checking outdated CA

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

body: From reading the chromium issue, validity length checks only apply to leaf certificates, not CAs.  This means your CA can still be valid for 20 years (mine is), so long as mitmproxy's generated leaf certificates are only valid for 39 months or less.  Since mitmproxy always generates certs on the fly, and never caches them to disk, checking for expiration of them only matters in really long running instances (usually mitmdump).
